title: Mike Phelan explains key reason Man Utd’s form has dipped under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
text:
Mike Phelan rejoined Manchester United as Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s assistant in December (Picture: Getty)

Mike Phelan insists it was inevitable Manchester United’s form would deteriorate under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer given how hard the pair worked the squad following their returns to the club.

The pair were appointed last December following the acrimonious departure of Jose Mourinho and immediately set about restoring the feel-good factor at Old Trafford, presiding over a run of 10 wins in 11 matches and masterminding an astonishing record breaking Champions League comeback victory over PSG.

United subsequently made Solskjaer’s appointment a permanent one following the 3-1 victory in Paris, but result have dipped ever since.

Solskjaer’s side missed out on a top four place and have failed to win any of their last six matches in all competitions, slipping perilously close to the relegation zone in the process.

‘We’d taken them from nothing to sky high, but they bottomed out because it was just too much, they weren’t prepared for it,’ Phelan told The Athletic. ‘So we had a lot of things to work on.

Mike Phelan enjoyed a successful spell working under Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United (Picture: Getty)

‘Ole relates well with the players, he understands what Man United is. It is definitely a difficult moment, but Ole hasn’t got his team yet.

‘He’s had three players (signed), you need more than three to be the manager of your own team.

‘We can build on something, I think. Ole just needs that opportunity to create the culture again.’

Phelan served under Sir Alex Ferguson, playing a crucial role in the club’s 2008 Champions League success but admitted he was nervous about returning to Carrington following a five-year absence.

He added: ‘I was down at Burnley College doing a coaching day and out on the pitch. About 3 o’clock, I finish and turn my phone on.

‘There is a call from Ole and another from Ed Woodward. Ole offered me the job and there was no real discussion. ‘Yeah, I’ll do it.’

‘Going back into Carrington, I was really, really nervous. We’d won the league by a canter when I left. But I didn’t know what to expect.

‘I had heard a lot of things in my time out about how it was operating. I just thought, ‘I’ll be myself.’ And it was like I’d never been away. Surreal. We just brought back a bit of a feelgood factor.’
